fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f\colon A\to B and any subobject m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A, F\forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf {Sub}(FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.

A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.

Then by the pasting lemma, f^{*}\Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}(m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf {Sub}(C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
Then both \forall _{k}h^{*} and g^{*}\forall _{f} are right adjoint to f^{*}\exists _{g}, so \forall _{k}h^{*} \cong g^{*}\forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.
Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

Fix a subobject m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) may be described as \exists _{m}m^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf {Sub}(A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}}\colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2})\to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f\colon B\to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {f^{*}(A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f^{*}\forall _{m}m^{*}(A_{2})\\ &\cong \forall _{n}g^{*}m^{*}(A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$}\\ &\cong \forall _{n}n^{*}f^{*}(A_{2})\\ &=: f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi in M is a subobject {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) defined recursively on the structure of \varphi as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \wedge \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the intersection of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \vee \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the union of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\lnot \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting negation of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the image of the following composite: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A) \xrightarrow {\pi } M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) where \pi is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is \forall _{\pi }({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}), where \forall _{\pi } is the right adjoint associated with a Heyting category and \pi \colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A)\to M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary union of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary intersection of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

A regular category \mathcal {C} is said to be coherent if each \mathsf {Sub}(B) has finite unions and each f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) preserves them. A coherent functor between coherent categories is a regular functor which preserves finite unions.
